task.Question: What writer is quoted by Merriam-Webster for the Word of the Day from June 27, 2022?

Annotator Metadata.Steps:
1. Search "merriam-webster word of the day" on Google search.
2. Opened the top "Word of the Day" result from the Merriam-Webster dictionary online.
3. Clicked "SEE ALL WORDS OF THE DAY" at the bottom.
4. Scrolled down to June 27, 2022.
5. Opened the Word of the Day ("jingoism").
6. Scrolled down and identified context quote for "jingoism".
7. Noted the name attributed to the quote.
Annotator Metadata.Tools:
1. Web browser
2. Search engine
3. Audio capability

steps.content: What writer is quoted by Merriam-Webster for the Word of the Day from June 27, 2022?

plan: Search the web for Merriam-Webster's Word of the Day for June 27, 2022.
Locate the specific entry for that date on the Merriam-Webster website or a reliable source.
Identify the writer quoted in the Word of the Day entry.
Extract the relevant information regarding the writer and their quote.

 Est. 1828

Word of the Day
===============

 : June 27, 2022

jingoism
--------

[play](javascript:void(0) "Listen to the pronunciation of jingoism")

noun

JING\-goh\-iz\-im

[Prev](/word-of-the-day/culminate-2022-06-26)
[Next](/word-of-the-day/fulsome-2022-06-28)

---

What It Means
-------------

*Jingoism* is excessive patriotism or nationalism, especially when marked by a belligerent foreign policy.

// When the war began many people were caught up in a wave of *jingoism*.

[See the entry \>](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/jingoism)

jingoism in Context
-------------------

"War is bad for culture. Not least of all because it turns our cultural institutions into bastions of *jingoism*." — Annie Levin, *The New York Observer*, 7 Mar. 2022

### Build your vocabulary! Get Word of the Day in your inbox every day.

[Test Your Vocabulary](/games)

---

* ![sequel spelled three ways with the incorrect ways crossed out and the correct spelling circled](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==)
* Rachel seemed to be \_\_\_\_\_ in every endeavor she started.

* [successful](/games/commonly-misspelled-quiz-2?q=4546&a=16848)
[successfull](/games/commonly-misspelled-quiz-2?q=4546&a=16850)
* [sucessful](/games/commonly-misspelled-quiz-2?q=4546&a=16851)
[succesful](/games/commonly-misspelled-quiz-2?q=4546&a=16849)

![Spell It](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==)

Hear a word and type it out. How many can you get right?

[TAKE THE QUIZ](/games/spell-it)

![Play Blossom: Solve today's spelling word game by finding as many words as you can using just 7 letters. Longer words score more points.](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw==)

Pick the best words!

[PLAY](/games/blossom-word-game)

---

Did You Know?
-------------

*Jingoism* originated during the Russo\-Turkish War of 1877\-1878, when many British citizens were hostile toward Russia and felt Britain should intervene in the conflict. Supporters of the cause expressed their sentiments in a music\-hall ditty with this refrain:

> We don't want to fight, yet by jingo if we do,
>
>
> We've got the ships, we've got the men,
>
>
> We've got the money, too!

Someone holding the attitude implied in the song became known as a *jingo* or *jingoist*, and the attitude itself was dubbed *jingoism*. The *jingo* in the tune is probably a euphemism for *Jesus*.

---
